unnormalised: What are some things to keep in mind when applying for Master's programs in India?
normalised: What are some things to keep in mind when applying for Master's programs in India?

unnormalised: Well, first off, start early! The application deadlines for many top institutions like IIT Delhi and IIM Ahmedabad can be as early as Dec 15th or Jan 31st. Make sure your GRE scores are valid (usually 5 yrs), and if required by the program. Also, remember that some universities, such as JNU, have their own entrance exams, so check that date.
normalised: Well, first off, start early! The application deadlines for many top institutions like I-I-T Delhi and I-I-M Ahmedabad can be as early as December fifteenth or January thirty first. Make sure your G-R-E scores are valid (usually five years), and if required by the program. Also, remember that some universities, such as J-N-U, have their own entrance exams, so check that date.

unnormalised: Secondly, focus on your Statement of Purpose (SOP). This is where you showcase your research interests, past experiences, and how the specific program aligns with your career goals. Mention relevant projects you've done, especially those with professors like Dr. Sharma or Dr. Kapoor. Tailor your SOP to each program; a generic one won’t cut it. Also, your undergraduate percentage matters. A score of 60% and above is generally considered good, but competitive programs often expect 75%+.
normalised: Secondly, focus on your Statement of Purpose (S-O-P). This is where you showcase your research interests, past experiences, and how the specific program aligns with your career goals. Mention relevant projects you've done, especially those with professors like Doctor Sharma or Doctor Kapoor. Tailor your S-O-P to each program; a generic one won’t cut it. Also, your undergraduate percentage matters. A score of sixty percent and above is generally considered good, but competitive programs often expect seventy five percent plus.

unnormalised: Finally, consider the fees and scholarship options. Many institutions offer scholarships based on merit or financial need. Check the university websites for details. For example, IITs often offer TA/RA positions that come with a stipend. The cost of an MBA from IIM Bangalore can be quite hefty, around Rs. 25 lakh, so explore all possible funding avenues before you apply.
